headline.main: Biscuit Recipes (the Dog May Lick the Bowl)

docs.lead_paragraph: IF you are willing to make an educated commitment to cooking for your dog, that's fine, veterinarians say. Otherwise, use a good commercial brand, picked by reading labels carefully. Canine nutritionists usually advise using dry dog food, flavored, perhaps, with a few spoonfuls of canned dog food or broth. Dry dog food, which contains about 10 percent water, is generally much denser in nutrients than canned dog food, which can contain up to 80 percent water. Dry, crunchy dog food also provides a good dental workout. Both sturdy meat bones and carrots act as jaw exercisers and natural tooth cleaners. Avoid foods that contain meat, fish or poultry byproducts.
